title: FK Mladost Lučani
text:
FK Mladost Lučani () is a professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> club based in <a href="Lu%C4%8Dani">Lučani</a>, <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>. They compete in the <a href="Serbian%20SuperLiga">Serbian SuperLiga</a>, the top tier of the <a href="Serbian%20football%20league%20system">national league system</a>.
History.
Founded in 1952, the club achieved its first notable success by winning the <a href="Yugoslav%20Inter-Republic%20League">Yugoslav Inter-Republic League</a> (Group East) in 1989, thus earning promotion to the <a href="Yugoslav%20Second%20League">Yugoslav Second League</a>. However, they were relegated after just <a href="1989%E2%80%9390%20Yugoslav%20Second%20League">one season</a>, finishing bottom of the table.
Upon the <a href="breakup%20of%20Yugoslavia">breakup of Yugoslavia</a>, the club started off in the <a href="Second%20League%20of%20FR%20Yugoslavia">Second League of FR Yugoslavia</a>. They won first place in <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20Second%20League%20of%20FR%20Yugoslavia">1995</a> and took promotion to the <a href="First%20League%20of%20FR%20Yugoslavia">First League</a> (I/B League). The club spent the following three seasons in the First League (the last two in the I/A League), before suffering relegation in <a href="1997%E2%80%9398%20First%20League%20of%20FR%20Yugoslavia">1998</a>. They earned another promotion to the top flight after winning the Second League (Group West) in <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Second%20League%20of%20FR%20Yugoslavia">2001</a>, but were narrowly relegated back the <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20First%20League%20of%20FR%20Yugoslavia">next year</a>. Regardless, the club's striker <a href="Zoran%20%C4%90ura%C5%A1kovi%C4%87">Zoran Đurašković</a> was crowned the competition's top scorer with 27 goals.
After winning the <a href="Serbian%20First%20League">Serbian First League</a> in <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20Serbian%20First%20League">2007</a>, the club was promoted to the <a href="Serbian%20SuperLiga">Serbian SuperLiga</a>. They placed in the middle of the table in their <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Serbian%20SuperLiga">debut appearance</a>, but were forced to withdraw from the competition due to financial issues. Over the next six seasons, the club played in the Serbian First League, the second tier of the national league pyramid. They earned promotion back to the SuperLiga after winning the First League in <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Serbian%20First%20League">2013–14</a>. With a seventh-place finish in its <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20Serbian%20SuperLiga">comeback season</a>, the club tied its previous record from the 2007–08 campaign. Moreover, <a href="Patrick%20Friday%20Eze">Patrick Friday Eze</a> concluded the season as the league's top scorer with 15 goals.
Led by manager <a href="Nenad%20Milovanovi%C4%87">Nenad Milovanović</a>, the club achieved its best ever league standing in the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Serbian%20SuperLiga">2016–17 season</a>, finishing in fourth place and securing a spot in European competitions for the first time in history. They were, however, eliminated by Azerbaijani side <a href="FC%20Inter%20Baku">Inter Baku</a> in the first qualifying round of the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2017–18 UEFA Europa League</a>, losing 5–0 on aggregate. On the domestic stage, the club made another historical success by reaching the final of the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Serbian%20Cup">2017–18 Serbian Cup</a>. They eventually lost 2–1 to <a href="FK%20Partizan">Partizan</a> after initially leading 1–0.
Honours.
<a href="Second%20League%20of%20FR%20Yugoslavia">Second League of FR Yugoslavia</a> / <a href="Serbian%20First%20League">Serbian First League</a> (Tier 2)
<a href="Yugoslav%20Inter-Republic%20League">Yugoslav Inter-Republic League</a> / <a href="Serbian%20League%20West">Serbian League West</a> (Tier 3)
